{{vgrelease|NA= November 11, 1993}} {{vgrelease|EU= November 11, 1993}}{{vgrelease|JP= November 12, 1993}}'''Nintendo Entertainment System'''
{{vgrelease|EU= December 31, 1994}} |genre = [[Action game|Action]], [[Platform game|Platform]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |ratings = [[Videogame Rating Council|VRC]]: GA |platforms = [[Mega Drive|Mega Drive/Genesis]], [[Amiga]], [[MS-DOS]], [[Nintendo Entertainment System|NES]], [[Game Boy]], [[Game Boy Color]] |media = [[Cartridge (electronics)|ROM cartridge]] |requirements = |input = [[Game controller]] }} '''''Disney's Aladdin''''' is a series of [[video game]]s based on the 1992 [[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|motion picture of the same name]]. Unlike most [[cross-platform]] games, the five versions ([[Sega Mega Drive]], [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]], [[Sega Master System]]/[[Sega Game Gear]], [[Game Boy]] and [[Nintendo Entertainment System|NES]]) are each significantly different games rather than all being ports of a single source. ==Mega Drive/Genesis version== The game from Virgin based on the 1992 animated Disney film. Initially released on the [[Mega Drive|Sega Mega Drive/Genesis]] [[video game console|console]], ''Aladdin'' is a side-scrolling [[platform game|platformer]]. The [[Mega Drive|Mega Drive/Genesis]] version was released in [[1993 in video gaming|1993]] jointly by [[Virgin Interactive]] and [[Sega]]. The game, which was notable for its use of [[Traditional animation|cel animation]] for in-game [[computer graphics|graphic]] elements, was produced by [[Virgin Interactive|Virgin Games USA]], a development studio which consisted of many members who would later form [[Shiny Entertainment]] and work on ''[[Earthworm Jim]]'', including Mike Dietz and [[David Perry (game developer)|David Perry]] himself (who supposedly coded the game in 3 months). Also involved were veteran game designer [[David Bishop]] and animators [[Andy Luckey]] and Ian Freedman. Five original compositions and five arrangements from the movie were composed by Donald S. Griffin at the request of Virgin's audio director, [[Tommy Tallarico]], who did the Mega Drive/Genesis instruments and incidental transition music. The Mega Drive/Genesis version was worked on by Disney animators under the supervision of Virgin's Animation Producer [[Andy Luckey]] and Virgin animators Mike Dietz and Ian Freedman. This was achieved by use of the "Digicel" process -- developed at Virgin Interactive by David Perry, Andy Astor, Andy Luckey and Dr. [[Stephen Clarke-Willson]]. The process compressed the data from the animator's drawings into the limited data storage capacity of the Sega Mega Drive/Genesis cartridge Horowitz, Ken: [http://www.sega-16.com/feature_page.php?id=169&title=Interview:%20Dr.%20Stephen%20Clarke-Willson Interview with Dr. Stephen Clarke-Willson] Accessed February 12, 2008 ===Game design=== The player controls [[Aladdin (Disney character)|Aladdin]], who must make his way through several levels based on locations from the movie: from the streets and rooftops of Agrabah, the Cave of Wonders and the Sultan's dungeon to the final confrontation in Grand Vizier [[Jafar (Aladdin)|Jafar]]'s palace. The Sultan's guards and also animals of the desert want to hinder Aladdin in his way. He can attack either close range with a scimitar, which can deflect certain projectiles, or long range with a limited supply of apples. Next to apples, Aladdin can also collect gems which can be traded for lives and continues with a traveling trader. Finding [[Genie (Aladdin)|Genie]] or Abu icons enables bonus rounds. The Genie bonus round is a game of luck played for apples, gems or extra lives, and continues until the player runs out of Genie tokens or lands on Jafar. In Abu's bonus round, the player controls the little monkey who has to catch bonus items that fall from the sky, but without touching any of the unwanted objects like rocks and pots. ===Ports=== An NES game was released in Europe based on this version. It was also ported, unofficially, twice more to the NES under the names ''Super Aladdin'' and ''Aladdin 2''; ''Super Aladdin'' is generally considered superior to the official port. The (original) NES version was in turn also made into a Game Boy version, which was compatible with the [[Super Game Boy]] and later ported to [[Game Boy Color]]. The PC versions ([[Amiga]] and [[DOS]]) were also based on the Mega Drive/Genesis version. The only differences in the PC version from the console one are a different HUD and improved music and sound effects. ==SNES version== {{Infobox VG | title = Aladdin |image = |developer = [[Capcom]] |publisher = [[Capcom]] |designer = [[Shinji Mikami]] |composer = Yuki Iwai

{{vgrelease|JP= August 1, 2003}} {{vgrelease|EU= March 19, 2004}}{{vgrelease|NA=September 28, 2004}} |genre = [[Action game|Action]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]], [[Game Boy Advance]], [[Nintendo Entertainment System|NES]] (unofficial) and [[Mega Drive|Mega Drive/Genesis]] (unofficial), [[MS-DOS]] (unofficial), [[Amiga]] (unofficial) |media = |requirements = |input = [[Game controller]] }} [[Image:Aladdin Pic 3.png|thumb|left|One of the side-scrolling stages.]] The Super Nintendo version of ''Aladdin'' was developed and published by [[Capcom]]. Unlike the [[Mega Drive|Sega Mega Drive]] version of the game, the player does not equip a [[scimitar]]. Instead, the gameplay revolves around jumping on enemies, as well as vaulting off stumps to reach otherwise inaccessible areas, though like the Genesis version, the player can also throw apples to stun opponents. The storyline more or less closely follows the plot of its namesake, the Disney full-length animated motion picture, with Aladdin going from a street rat to a prince, who first woos, and then has to rescue, the [[Princess Jasmine]]. Most levels and stages of the game will be readily recognized by people who have seen the motion picture, but there are a few levels that have nothing to do with the movieâincluding an Egyptian pyramid and a surreal world where [[Genie]]âdressed in a [[tuxedo]]âserves as Aladdin's guide (this level represents [[Genie]]'s song sequence [[Friend Like Me]], and has an [[instrumental]] version of that song playing in the background). The game features renditions of the soundtrack from the Disney motion picture, as well as several mini-games dependent on the player catching a golden [[Scarabaeidae|scarab]] or collecting all diamonds within a stage. An extra challenge involved finding 70 red diamonds throughout the game. While they weren't necessary for ending the game, the credits screen changes slightly according to how many diamonds were collected. That version sold over 1.75 million units worldwide. Platinum List (Capcom's Bestsellers) [http://ir.capcom.co.jp/english/data/million.html Capcom Investor Relations Page] Accessed February 12, 2008 {{cite web|url=http://www.capcom.co.jp/ir/english/data/pdf/fy2002b_e.pdf|title=Company Profile|publisher=[[Capcom]]|accessdate=2011-02-15|date=May 2002}} [[Image:Aladdin Pic 8.png|thumb|left|Aladdin on the flying carpet.]] The reason that the Super Nintendo version of Aladdin was developed by Capcom and not [[Virgin Interactive]] was that the film came out at a time when Capcom held the licensing rights to games on Nintendo consoles based on Disney intellectual property. This deal resulted in some classic titles as ''[[DuckTales (video game)|DuckTales]]'', ''[[Darkwing Duck (Capcom)|Darkwing Duck]]'', ''[[Who Framed Roger Rabbit (NES game)|Who Framed Roger Rabbit?]]'' (Game Boy version), and ''[[Goof Troop (video game)|Goof Troop]]''. The license expired some time between the cinematic releases of ''Aladdin'' and ''[[The Lion King]]'', as the [[The Lion King (video game)|videogame adaptation of ''The Lion King'']] was developed by Virgin Interactive on all platforms including the Super Nintendo, and the Mega Drive version of ''Aladdin'' was ported to the NES for a European release on New Year's Eve 1994. The Capcom version was also ported unofficially to the NES by [http://bootleggames.wikia.com/wiki/Hummer_Team Hummer Team] in 1995. It was also ported unofficially to the Mega Drive/Genesis. A version of the game would also later receive a port for the [[Game Boy Advance]] with an extra stage, though all the songs based directly on the original movie were replaced with new music. ==Master System/Game Gear version== {{Infobox VG | title = Aladdin |image = |developer = [[SIMS Co., Ltd.|SIMS]] |publisher = [[Sega]] |designer = |composer = Yoko Wada |engine = |released = '''Game Gear'''

{{vgrelease|EU= 1994}} |genre = [[Action game|Action]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Sega Game Gear]], [[Sega Master System]] |media = |requirements = |input = [[Game controller]] }} This version was developed by [[SIMS Co., Ltd.|SIMS]] and published by [[Sega]], and released in 1994 for the [[Sega Game Gear]] worldwide and for the [[Sega Master System]] in Europe. Sega went on to produce this game since they already had the necessary [[intellectual property]] licensing rights in order to publish the [[Virgin Interactive]] game on the Mega Drive/Genesis. The game is basically the same on both systems, except for the screen size. Gameplay in much of the game resembles ''[[Flashback (video game)|Flashback: The Quest for Identity]]'' or ''[[Prince of Persia]]''. ==Reception== ''Aladdin'' was awarded Best Genesis Game of 1993 by ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]''. They also awarded it Best Animation.{{cite journal |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1994 |month= |title=Electronic Gaming Monthly's Buyer's Guide |journal= |volume= |issue= |pages= |id= |url= |accessdate=2009-01-09 |quote= }} The game was reviewed in 1994 in ''[[Dragon (magazine)|Dragon]]'' #211 by Jay & Dee in the "Eye of the Monitor" column.
